record.author: Isaeus
record.date_source: (2007). Isaeus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Chronology depending on how editors understand the reference to the Pythian festival, either after the Third Sacred War (spring 354 BC), or during the 107th Olympiad (350/349 BC).

record.print_edition: Isaeus. Forster, Edward Seymour, editor. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press; London: William Heinemann Ltd., 1927 (1962 printing).
record.author: Isaeus
record.date_source: (2007). Isaeus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Upper and lower limits according to Edwards.

record.print_edition: Isaeus. Forster, Edward Seymour, editor. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press; London: William Heinemann Ltd., 1927 (1962 printing).
record.author: Isaeus
record.date_source: (2007). Isaeus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Some commentators suggest a later date, at the end of 360s. Since it is mentioned that Astyphilus served throughout the Theban War, Edwards argues that the speech was certainly written after 371 BC.

record.title_from_print_edition: Πρὸς Ξεναίνετον περὶ τοῦ Ἀριστάρχου κλήρου
record.print_edition: Isaeus. Forster, Edward Seymour, editor. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press; London: William Heinemann Ltd., 1927 (1962 printing).
record.author: Isaeus
record.date_source: (2007). Isaeus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Most commentators agree with this date. Wevers argues for a date of circa 355 BC.

record.print_edition: Isaeus. Forster, Edward Seymour, editor. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press; London: William Heinemann Ltd., 1927 (1962 printing).
record.author: Isaeus
record.date_source: (2007). Isaeus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Edwards supports a date of circa early 350s, because the estate had been awarded to Philomache II, in 361/360 BC, and was later contested.

record.print_edition: Isaeus. Forster, Edward Seymour, editor. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press; London: William Heinemann Ltd., 1927 (1962 printing).
record.author: Isaeus
record.date_source: (2007). Isaeus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Edwards argues that this speech was delivered 2 years after the archonship of Archias, which took place in 346/345 BC.

record.author: Oppian
record.date_source: Oxford Classical Dictionary: Oppian
record.comment_on_chronology: This poem is addressed to the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius and his son Commodus, therefore it was composed before his death in 180 AD.

record.print_edition: The Speeches of Aeschines. Adams, Charles Darwin, editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1919.
record.author: Aeschines
record.date_source: (2000). Aeschines. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Safe date, but with difficulty for an even more precise date.

record.print_edition: The Speeches of Aeschines. Adams, Charles Darwin, editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1919.
record.author: Aeschines
record.date_source: (2000). Aeschines. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: This speech was written for a trial that took place in the summer of 343 BC, with Aeschines defending himself from the accusations of Demosthenes.

record.print_edition: The Speeches of Aeschines. Adams, Charles Darwin, editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1919.
record.author: Aeschines
record.date_source: (2000). Aeschines. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Safe date, delivered against Ctesiphon, a political ally of Demosthenes, in 330 BC, with a deadly of 6 years from the initial prosecution by Aeschines.

record.print_edition: Andocides. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 1. Maidment, K. J., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1941.
record.author: Andocides
record.date_source: 1998). Antiphon and Andocides. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Safe date, Andocides defended himself against a prosecution for endeixis related to the Eleusinian Mysteries.

record.print_edition: Andocides. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 1. Maidment, K. J., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1941.
record.author: Andocides
record.date_source: 1998). Antiphon and Andocides. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Safe date, this speech was delivered after Andocides returned from his exile in 410 BC and successfully persuaded the magistrates to allow him to address the Athenian Assembly.

record.print_edition: Andocides. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 1. Maidment, K. J., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1941.
record.author: Andocides
record.date_source: 1998). Antiphon and Andocides. New York, USA: University of Texas Press

record.print_edition: Antiphon. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 1. Maidment, K. J., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1941.
record.author: Antiphon
record.date_source: 1998). Antiphon and Andocides. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: The exact date is unknown but according to the author is usually placed between 420 and 411 BC.

record.print_edition: Antiphon. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 1. Maidment, K. J., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1941.
record.author: Antiphon
record.date_source: 1998). Antiphon and Andocides. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: The speech is dated about a decade after the Mytilinean revolt in 427 BC.

record.print_edition: Antiphon. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 1. Maidment, K. J., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1941.
record.author: Antiphon
record.date_source: 1998). Antiphon and Andocides. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Council. According to Gagarin and MacDowell, this year the Choregus' tribe was assigned the first Prytany, which at the time was always 37 days long. He tells us he served 35 of these days (all but two) and earlier (6.44) that he served for 20 days of Metageitnion (the second month).We can thus calculate that the new Council began its service that year on the 16th day of Hekatombaion (the ®rst month), and the evidence of inscriptions informs us that this happened in 419/8 bc and in no other year near this.

record.print_edition: Dinarchus. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 2. Burtt, J. O., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1954.
record.author: Dinarchus
record.date_source: (2001). Dinarchus, Hyperides, and Lycurgus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Hyperides was among among the 10 citizens appointed to prosecute Demosthenes. The trial took place in 323 BC.

record.print_edition: Dinarchus. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 2. Burtt, J. O., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1954.
record.author: Dinarchus
record.date_source: (2001). Dinarchus, Hyperides, and Lycurgus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: The authors mention that this speech was composed probably before the Harpalus affair in 324 BC.

record.print_edition: Dinarchus. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 2. Burtt, J. O., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1954.
record.author: Dinarchus
record.date_source: (2001). Dinarchus, Hyperides, and Lycurgus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Philocles was tried alongside Demosthenes in the same trial, therefore this speech was also composed in 323 BC.

record.print_edition: Hyperides. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 2. Burtt, J. O., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1954.
record.author: Hyperides
record.date_source: (2001). Dinarchus, Hyperides, and Lycurgus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: The trial for which this speech was composed most probably took place in 333 BC.

record.date_source: (2001). Dinarchus, Hyperides, and Lycurgus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: The trial for which this speech was written took place after the battle of Chaeronia in 338 BC, but before the death of Phillip the II in 336 BC.

record.print_edition: Hyperides. Minor Attic Orators, Vol. 2. Burtt, J. O., editor. London: William Heinemann, Ltd.; Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1954.

record.date_source: (2001). Dinarchus, Hyperides, and Lycurgus. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: The trial for which the speech was composed took place several years before the Battle of Chaeronea and before the death of Alexander.

record.print_edition: Hanno, Periplus; Geographi graeci minores Volumen Primum, ed. Karl Müller; Ambroise Firmin Didot, Paris, 1855
record.author: Hanno
record.date_source: Making Specimens in the Periplus of Hanno and its Imperial Tradition
record.comment_on_chronology: Different scholars propose different dates, all of them falling between the 5th and the 1st centuries BC.

record.print_edition: Scylax of Caranda. Geographi Graeci Minores, Volume 1. Müller, Karl. Paris: Ambroise Firmin Didot, 1855.
record.author: Scylax of Caryanda
record.date_source: Shipley, G. (2019). Pseudo-Skylax’s Periplous: The Circumnavigation of the Inhabited World: Text, Translation and Commentary (DGO-Digital original, 2). Liverpool University Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Shipley argues for a strict date of 338-337 BC, supported by Müller, based on the inclusion of the names of coastal cities in the region of Messenia, which Phillip the II removed from the sphere of Spartan influence after the Battle of Chaeronea in 338 BC.

record.print_edition: Dicaearchus, Messenius (Pseudo); Heraclides, Criticus, author; Geographi Graeci Minores, Volumen Primum, ed. Karl Müller; Ambroise Firmin Didot, Paris, 1855
record.author: Heraclides, Criticus
record.date_source: McInerney, J. (2012). Heraclides Criticus and the Problem of Taste. In Aesthetic Value in Classical Antiquity. Leiden, The Netherlands: Brill

record.print_edition: Agatharchides, creator; Geographi graeci minores Volumen Primum, ed. Karl Müller; Ambroise Firmin Didot, Paris, 1855
record.author: Agatharchides
record.date_source: Sacks, K. (2016, March 07). Agatharchides, of Cnidus, Greek historian, geographer, and Peripatetic philosopher, c. 215–after 145 BCE. Oxford Classical Dictionary
record.comment_on_chronology: Written probably during his stay in Alexandria, as he spent there the great majority of his life before fleeing to Athens in 145 BC.

record.print_edition: Pseudo-Scymnus, creator; Geographi graeci minores Volumen Primum, ed. Karl Müller; Ambroise Firmin Didot, Paris, 1855
record.author: Pseudo-Scymnus
record.date_source: Wikipedia, Pseydo-Scymnus
record.comment_on_chronology: Diller determining the author to be Pausanias of Damascus, who lived around 100 BC in Bithynia, hence the chronology of this work.

record.print_edition: Isidore, of Charax. Geographi graeci minores, Volume 1. Müller, Karl, editor. Paris: Ambroise Firmin Didot, 1855.
record.author: Isidore, of Charax
record.date_source: Molina Marín, A. I. (2010). Imperio y cartografía en la época imperial romana: Orbis romanum et orbis terrarum. Antigüedad y Cristianismo, (27), 241–256
record.comment_on_chronology: Martinez cites a passage in the work, where the rebellion of Tiridates II against the the Parthian king Fraates IV is mentioned, an event which took place in 26 BC.

record.title_labels: Anonymi (Arriani, ut fertur) periplus maris Erythraei
record.title_from_print_edition: Anonymi (Arriani, ut fertur) periplus maris Erythraei
record.print_edition: Pseudo-Arrianus. Geographi graeci minores, Volume 1. Müller, Karl, editor. Paris: Ambroise Firmin Didot, 1855.
record.author: Pseudo-Arrianus
record.date_source: Huntingford, G.W.B. (Ed.). (2010). The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, by an unknown author: With some extracts from Agatharkhides On the Erythraean Sea (1st ed.). Hakluyt Society
record.comment_on_chronology: Based on four passages inside this work, on of which mentions the reign of King Nahapana, who ascended the throne in 95 AD, Huntington aruges for a date range between 95 and 130 AD.

record.print_edition: Arrian. Arriani Nicomediensis Scripta Minora. Hercher, Rudolf; Eberhard, Alfred, editors. Leipzig: Teubner, 1885.
record.author: Arrian
record.date_source: Leon, D. (2021). Arrian the Historian: Writing the Greek Past in the Roman Empire. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Based on a declaration by Arrian himself, that he wrote his work on the 20th year of Emperor Hadrian's reign.

record.print_edition: Arrian. Arriani Nicomediensis Scripta Minora. Hercher, Rudolf; Eberhard, Alfred, editors. Leipzig: Teubner, 1885.
record.author: Arrian
record.date_source: Leon, D. (2021). Arrian the Historian: Writing the Greek Past in the Roman Empire. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Leon argues that Acies Contra Alanos cannot have been written much later than the events it describes.

record.print_edition: Arrian. Arriani Nicomediensis Scripta Minora. Hercher, Rudolf; Eberhard, Alfred, editors. Leipzig: Teubner, 1885.
record.author: Arrian
record.date_source: Leon, D. (2021). Arrian the Historian: Writing the Greek Past in the Roman Empire. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Leon believes that, due to in-text references to contemporary events, Periplous can be dated to 131-132 AD.

record.print_edition: Arrian. Flavii Arriani Anabasis Alexandri. Roos, A. G., editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1907.
record.author: Arrian
record.date_source: Leon, D. (2021). Arrian the Historian: Writing the Greek Past in the Roman Empire. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Leon argues that on account of Arrian's established fame and statesmanship, this work was written during the decade of the 120s, certainly before Arrian assumed his duties as imperial legate in 131/132 AD.

record.print_edition: Arrian. Arriani Nicomediensis Scripta Minora. Hercher, Rudolf; Eberhard, Alfred, editors. Leipzig: Teubner, 1885.
record.author: Arrian
record.date_source: Leon, D. (2021). Arrian the Historian: Writing the Greek Past in the Roman Empire. New York, USA: University of Texas Press
record.comment_on_chronology: Leon argues that Arrian wrote this work around the time he assumed his duties as Eponymous Archon of Athens, in 145/146 AD, when he was 60 years old.

record.comment_on_chronology: Gladys Shoemaker argues that the best argument that can be made for dating Dionysius' works is that all of them were composed between 30 and 7 BC, as frequently he would pause writing on one work to begin another.

record.comment_on_chronology: According to Kappraff, little is known about the life on Nicomachus, which can be approximated between the mid 1st to mid 2nd century AD, hence the date.

record.print_edition: Nicomachus of Gerasa. Musici Scriptores Graeci. Jan, Karl von, editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1895.

record.print_edition: Cleonides. Musici Scriptores Graeci. Jan, Karl von, editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1895.
record.author: Cleonides
record.date_source: Cleonides, Wikipedia
record.comment_on_chronology: Evdn though treatises with the name eisagoge could be established between the 3rd and the 4th centuries BC, internal evidence from the text points out towards the 1st century BC, which seems the most likely period for Cleonide's work according to John Solomon.

record.print_edition: Claudius Ptolemaeus. Claudii Ptolemaei Opera quae exstant omnia, Volume 1, Part 1-2. Heiberg, J.L., editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1898-1903.
record.author: Claudius Ptolemaeus
record.date_source: Jones, A. Raymond (2024, April 3). Ptolemy. Encyclopedia Britannica
record.comment_on_chronology: This work was completed around 150 AD according to Jones.

record.print_edition: Claudius Ptolemaeus. Claudii Ptolemaei opera quae exstant omnia, Volume 3.1. Boll, Franz, and Boer, Emilie, editors. Leipzig: Teubner, 1954.
record.author: Claudius Ptolemaeus
record.date_source: Jones, A. Raymond (2024, April 3). Ptolemy. Encyclopedia Britannica
record.comment_on_chronology: Date based on the approximate life span of Ptolemy.

record.print_edition: Claudius Ptolemaeus. Musici Scriptores Graeci. Jan, Karl von, editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1895.
record.author: Claudius Ptolemaeus
record.date_source: Jones, A. Raymond (2024, April 3). Ptolemy. Encyclopedia Britannica
record.comment_on_chronology: Date based on the approximate life span of Ptolemy.

record.print_edition: Myia, Epistula ad Phyllidem. Epistolographi Graeci. Hercher, Rudolph, editor. Paris: A. F. Didot, 1873.
record.author: Myia
record.date_source: Myia, Wikipedia
record.comment_on_chronology: This work, probably spurious, is usually dated to the 3rd and 2nd centuries BC according to Plant.

record.print_edition: Epicharmus. Die Fragmente der Vorsokratiker, Vol. 1. Diels, Hermann, editor. Berlin: Weidmann, 1922.
record.author: Epicharmus
record.date_source: Poehlmann, E. (2015). Epicharmus and Aeschylus on Stage in Syracuse in the 5th Century. Greek and Roman Musical Studies, 3(1), 137-166
record.comment_on_chronology: According to Poehlmann, there is evidence of the floruit of Epicharnus starting in 486 BC. Moreover, he was based in Syracuse and met Aeschylus there around 472 BC, which gives the lower limit for the date.

record.print_edition: Pausanias. Pausaniae Graeciae descriptio, Volumes 1-3. Spiro, Friedrich, editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1903.
record.author: Pausanias
record.date_source: John Elsner, PAUSANIAS: A GREEK PILGRIM IN THE ROMAN WORLD, Past & Present, Volume 135, Issue 1, May 1992, Pages 3–29
record.comment_on_chronology: Elsner mentions that Pausanias travelled around Greece for about 30 years, hence the dating of this work.

record.print_edition: Septuaginta. The Old Testament in Greek According to the Septuagint. Volume 1: Genesis-IV Kings. Swete, Henry Barclay, editor. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1901.
record.author: Septuaginta
record.date_source: Tov, E. (1988). The Septuagint. In Mikra. Leiden, The Netherlands: Brill
record.comment_on_chronology: Tov mentions that according to the epistle of Aristeas, the Pentateuch was translated in the 3rd century BC, which is plausible according to him.

record.print_edition: Chariton, of Aphrodisias. Erotici Scriptores Graeci, Volume 2. Hercher, Rudolf, editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1859.

record.comment_on_chronology: Ruiz-Montero argues that based on linguistic style and proximity to authors such as PLutarch, Flavius Josephus and Philo, it is probable that Chariton composed this work between the last years of the 1st century and the first years of the 2nd century AD.

record.print_edition: Geminus. Γέμινου εισαγωγὴ ἐις τὰ φαινόμενα. Gemini Elementa astronomiae. Manitius, Charles, editor. Leipzig: Teubner, 1898.
record.author: Geminus
record.date_source: James Evans and J. Lennart Bergsen (2006), Gemino's Introduction to the Phenomena, New Jersey: Princeton University Press.
record.comment_on_chronology: Based on calculations regarding the Egyptian calendar and the mentioning of the festival of Isis, which was taking place at the end of December, Evans and Bergsen have concluded that Geminos wrote this work between the first and third part of the 1st century BC (pp.17-18).

record.print_edition: Harpocration, Valerius, creator; Dindorf, Wilhelm, 1802-1883, editor
record.author: Harpocration
record.date_source: Wilson, N. (2015, December 22). Harpocration, Valerius, of Alexandria (1), lexicographer. Oxford Classical Dictionary
record.comment_on_chronology: Wilson argues that the author is perhaps to be identified among the tutors of the Roman Emperor Verus, and his date is established by mentioning him in a papyrus letter of the 2nd cent. AD, which also shows that he was in touch with an intellectual circle in Oxyrhynchus.

record.print_edition: Hecataeus of Abderita. Die Fragmente der Vorsokratiker, Vol. 2. Diels, Hermann, editor. Berlin: Weidmann, 1922.

record.date_source: Murray, O., & Stern, M. (1973). Hecataeus of Abdera and Theophrastus on Jews and Egyptians. The Journal of Egyptian Archaeology, 59, 159–168
record.comment_on_chronology: Murray stresses that it is probable, though not certain, that Hecataeus wrote between 320 and 315 that his work was used by Theophrastus in the De lapidibus.
